tags: write a better movie if you don't want me to be salty about it M&M
summary: Now that we’re all talking about Endgame...
title: Now that we’re all talking about Endgame...
body:
I can side-eye Steve’s ending. Look, we all know that Steve Rogers deserves to Rest, and most of us were hoping to see him somehow survive that movie. However, there is not enough suspension of disbelief on this earth for me to believe that Steve “I will punch injustice directly in the face” Rogers is going to spend seventy years playing house and meekly trying not to put a hair on history’s head out of place while atrocities (that he knows about!) happen. 

Like I’m really supposed to pretend Steve’s gonna chill and raise 2.5 kids while the US government does McCarthyism and Jim Crow? The dude that has be punching up since he was 5′6 of health problems and rage is just…gonna spend a bunch of time trying to some toddler to say “grandpa” while the US military dumps Agent Orange on civilians? Like, he’s canonically a military history nerd who has polished up on every shitty thing that happened while he was taking his ice bath, and he’s just…gonna watch it all, quietly, while being like, “Hey Peggy! Sorry I zapped your original family out of existence! This one’s good, too, right?!”  

To say nothing of Bucky Barnes, the person he broke every rule for, over and over again. Steve “I’ll walk to Austria!!!!” Rogers is going to knowingly chill while Bucky is brainwashed and tortured for seventy years? 

Yeah, no. Back to pretending this movie doesn’t exist!

summary: i’ve already seen a post like this but it honest to god would FUCK me up if i got snapped but my little sister didn’t and then i...
body:
i’ve already seen a post like this but it honest to god would FUCK me up if i got snapped but my little sister didn’t and then i come back and suddenly she’s TWO years older than me and i’m the younger sister by default like WHAT THE FUCK

like ooo yeah it’s funny but i would probably freak the actual fuck out and just the thought of missing 5 years of my sister’s life and her now being the ‘eldest sister” gives me the WORST feeling in my stomach i hate it i hate it hate it

summary: Reading more excellent meta posts, and I’m assuming that TPTB for Endgame (Markus & McFeely? IDK) were planning at one point on...
body: Reading more excellent meta posts, and I’m assuming that TPTB for Endgame (Markus & McFeely? IDK) were planning at one point on Sharon being the one Steve ends up with, but after the negative reaction to her character in Civil War (because that whole side plot was written terribly), they went back to Peggy. At no point did they consider that Steve’s ending might not need to involve a girlfriend. This is just speculation, but I think when it became obvious that people didn’t get what was going on with Sharon, they pivoted back to Peggy. The thing is, I would so much rather he had ended up with Sharon! Even with the bad writing in Civil War, I would have preferred Steve end up with her, because at least then his arc of moving forward with his life in the 21st century would have stayed intact! I mean, obviously I would have preferred he didn’t have to end up with a girlfriend at all, because why force it? Why not lean into the friendships and the life he’s been working to build since he came into the 21st century? But I’m guessing they never seriously considered that for ‘reasons’ (heteronormativity) and couldn’t imagined anything outside of ‘Steve gets girl. Steve happy.’ But at least ending up with Sharon wouldn’t have destroyed his character!

title: 2019 Summer Movie Season
body:
“2019 Summer Movie Season” - The 10 movies I am most looking forward to this summer.

With Memorial Day comes the unofficial start of summer, and the unofficial start of the summer movie season. I know we have already seen big releases like “John Wick: Chapter 3 – Parabellum”, “Pokemon Detective Pikachu”, and…of course…”Avengers: Endgame”, but I wanted to take a look at what’s ahead over the coming months. So without further adieu, here are 10 movies I am excited about coming out…

summary: Avengers: Endgame Shows Us a Universe That Still Can’t Do Right By Women
title: Avengers: Endgame Shows Us a Universe That Still Can’t Do Right By Women
excerpt: When The Avengers first premiered, it was a team of five men and one woman. It is 2019, and the final journey of that originating Avengers team has come to a close, the first major arc of the Marve…
description:
I figured I would share this article in general since it does such a good job summing up many of the quibbles I had with Endgame with regard to its treatment of female characters. 

The article covers how the film handles Natasha, Carol, Okoye, Wanda, Gamora, Nebula, Valkyrie, Peggy, Pepper, and Morgan–and how it fails all of them. Here’s some choice quotes from the piece, but I highly encourage reading the whole thing for better context. 

Natasha:

Natasha’s inability to have children renders her—in the eyes of the narrative, and in her own summation—“less valuable” in terms of survival. After she’s gone, Tony Stark asks if she had family they should notify, and it’s pointed out again that the Avengers were the only ones she called family. All of this adds up to make it seem that Natasha’s only true value was in loving the Avengers (and Clint) enough to be willing to take that leap for all of them.

Carol, Okoye, & Wanda:

Carol is brilliant throughout Endgame, but she’s also underused because she’s not been given any time at all to acclimate to the group setting. This is not her farewell tour, so she only shows up in special bursts, powered by fists of space-energy and little else. The same is true of Okoye, who Marvel rightfully gave top billing to, but never the screen time to match. Wanda Maximoff also shows up briefly to flex her extraordinarily powerful magic muscles, but her only stake in the film is being pissed with Thanos for killing her boyfriend Vision. All her fury gets her nowhere, which is hardly surprising because these films have never known what to do with someone as powerful as the Scarlet Witch is meant to be. She’s always getting sidelined because dealing with her true skillset would make most of the other combatants seem superfluous.

Gamora & Nebula:

Gamora and Nebula are pulled through the wringer and then some in Endgame, the former already dead and brought back from her past, the latter forced to confront an earlier and far crueler version of herself that she eventually murders. […] Both Nebula and Gamora are extremely important to the plot of Endgame, with Nebula’s appearance in the past accidentally notifying Thanos as to the Avengers’ plans, and Gamora’s decision to trust the future version of her sister being integral to the success of said plans. But the film seems to forget them once things get heated up; one brief re-meet of Peter Quill and Gamora disappears to who knows where, with Nebula left behind to hitch a ride again with the Guardians. We have no idea if the two said a proper goodbye to one another, or how they are both feeling now that they have to relearn their relationship all over again.

Valkyrie: 

By the end, Thor abdicates the throne in her favor, noting that she has already been doing the job for him, and that she’s an excellent leader. These things are true, but Valkyrie also expressed a hatred of Asgardian monarchy when Thor met her first. And more to the point, no matter how good Val is at steering their people, she is essentially being made to shoulder Thor’s burden simply because he has decided he can’t handle it anymore. Rather than offering to help her set up a new form of government, or see that the transition of power goes smoothly, he just up and leaves all of his responsibilities on her plate.

Peggy:

While we’re supposed to be happy for Steve Rogers and Peggy Carter finally getting their dance on at the end of this, it’s hard not to be a little insulted over all the film is choosing to ignore in that tender moment. It is unclear if any of Peggy’s former trials will come to pass with Steve Rogers back in her life, and the idea of all of her adventures—in her own series Agent Carter and beyond—being overwritten for a life in a cute suburb with her man is frankly just as depressing as them losing one another. Peggy Carter claims to know her value, but in this moment, it’s hard to tell if the MCU knows it, or if they ever cared about it at all. Love is truly grand, but shoehorning Peggy in there for a kiss when we get no time with her at all feels like a particular kind of cheat.

Pepper & Morgan: 

[Heroic death] is one of fiction’s favorite noble ends, and it often sees a woman and a child who have to move on without a father and partner. And while it is great that Tony got to have some time with his daughter, she’s barely five years old, which means that her memory of him is bound to get fuzzy as she gets older. She is cheated out of that relationship while Pepper is left alone, after spending years panicked for Tony’s safety and well-being. It is the ending that Iron Man perhaps deserves, but it is not the ending that his family deserves, and there’s no way around that plain truth. But we’re conditioned to accept this as good and heroic tragedy, full of sorrow and therefore meaningful, rather than asking why these are always the people who pay the price for that heroism.

Natasha’s inability to have children renders her—in the eyes of the narrative, and in her own summation—“less valuable” in terms of survival. After she’s gone, Tony Stark asks if she had family they should notify, and it’s pointed out again that the Avengers were the only ones she called family. All of this adds up to make it seem that Natasha’s only true value was in loving the Avengers (and Clint) enough to be willing to take that leap for all of them.

Carol, Okoye, & Wanda:

Carol is brilliant throughout Endgame, but she’s also underused because she’s not been given any time at all to acclimate to the group setting. This is not her farewell tour, so she only shows up in special bursts, powered by fists of space-energy and little else. The same is true of Okoye, who Marvel rightfully gave top billing to, but never the screen time to match. Wanda Maximoff also shows up briefly to flex her extraordinarily powerful magic muscles, but her only stake in the film is being pissed with Thanos for killing her boyfriend Vision. All her fury gets her nowhere, which is hardly surprising because these films have never known what to do with someone as powerful as the Scarlet Witch is meant to be. She’s always getting sidelined because dealing with her true skillset would make most of the other combatants seem superfluous.

Gamora & Nebula:

Gamora and Nebula are pulled through the wringer and then some in Endgame, the former already dead and brought back from her past, the latter forced to confront an earlier and far crueler version of herself that she eventually murders. […] Both Nebula and Gamora are extremely important to the plot of Endgame, with Nebula’s appearance in the past accidentally notifying Thanos as to the Avengers’ plans, and Gamora’s decision to trust the future version of her sister being integral to the success of said plans. But the film seems to forget them once things get heated up; one brief re-meet of Peter Quill and Gamora disappears to who knows where, with Nebula left behind to hitch a ride again with the Guardians. We have no idea if the two said a proper goodbye to one another, or how they are both feeling now that they have to relearn their relationship all over again.

Valkyrie: 

By the end, Thor abdicates the throne in her favor, noting that she has already been doing the job for him, and that she’s an excellent leader. These things are true, but Valkyrie also expressed a hatred of Asgardian monarchy when Thor met her first. And more to the point, no matter how good Val is at steering their people, she is essentially being made to shoulder Thor’s burden simply because he has decided he can’t handle it anymore. Rather than offering to help her set up a new form of government, or see that the transition of power goes smoothly, he just up and leaves all of his responsibilities on her plate.

Peggy:

While we’re supposed to be happy for Steve Rogers and Peggy Carter finally getting their dance on at the end of this, it’s hard not to be a little insulted over all the film is choosing to ignore in that tender moment. It is unclear if any of Peggy’s former trials will come to pass with Steve Rogers back in her life, and the idea of all of her adventures—in her own series Agent Carter and beyond—being overwritten for a life in a cute suburb with her man is frankly just as depressing as them losing one another. Peggy Carter claims to know her value, but in this moment, it’s hard to tell if the MCU knows it, or if they ever cared about it at all. Love is truly grand, but shoehorning Peggy in there for a kiss when we get no time with her at all feels like a particular kind of cheat.

Pepper & Morgan: 

[Heroic death] is one of fiction’s favorite noble ends, and it often sees a woman and a child who have to move on without a father and partner. And while it is great that Tony got to have some time with his daughter, she’s barely five years old, which means that her memory of him is bound to get fuzzy as she gets older. She is cheated out of that relationship while Pepper is left alone, after spending years panicked for Tony’s safety and well-being. It is the ending that Iron Man perhaps deserves, but it is not the ending that his family deserves, and there’s no way around that plain truth. But we’re conditioned to accept this as good and heroic tragedy, full of sorrow and therefore meaningful, rather than asking why these are always the people who pay the price for that heroism.

tags: there are too many marias in marvel
summary: Natasha: They’re going to kill me off because apparently two high profile avenger ladies is too much on screen. Take care of...
body:
Natasha: They’re going to kill me off because apparently two high profile avenger ladies is too much on screen. Take care of them for me. And by them I mean Fury, Hill, and Parker.

Carol: I will. Oh, totally unrelated… Does Hill date women?

Natasha: 😏

summary: this “tom holland can’t shut up about spoilers so we literally give him a fake script and no context” thing was funny for a...
body: this “tom holland can’t shut up about spoilers so we literally give him a fake script and no context” thing was funny for a while but imagine trying to work like this. tom holland was 20 when he started playing spider-man. the first accidental spoilers were probably truly accidental because he was still inexperienced within this huge franchise and about how he should behave on press tours but for the russo brothers to only give him his lines and literally not tell him whom he’s acting with or what scene he is in (telling him he’s at a wedding instead of a funeral) is unprofessional. the fact that he can still act like he does with so little information is truly amazing but imagine if he was given a proper script and context.

summary:
You guys have nooo idea how badly I wanted to liveblog Endgame last night lmaooo
But! It definitely hurt a lot more the second...
body:
You guys have nooo idea how badly I wanted to liveblog Endgame last night lmaooo

But! It definitely hurt a lot more the second time bc I knew what was gonna happen

And I came up with a really funny thought I wanna share with y'all 😂

So you know how Nat only ate a pb sandwich? What if when Thanos snapped, grapes no longer existed (or at least the people who make jelly no longer existed) so she could only eat half of the pb&j sandwich?? lmaooo
